title: Will internet access become free in the future? - Quora

response.answer_text: Some responses to this question point out that ‘nothing is free’, and while that is true, that is not the ‘free’ that this response will use. The freedom under discussion is not the freedom from price, from the various dollar costs, but the freedom to use. The highways are not without cost, but we do not demand payment for the use of the highways. The highways are free and open. We ask that you pay for the coffee along the way, the burgers and fries, the Coca Cola, but *you* are free to use the highway. We will even provide rest stops with open space and toilet facilities, a water fountain. You can build a motel beside it and charge people to stay in your motel. If we demanded payment for the use of the highways, the cost of doing business would skyrocket. Business is the heaviest user of the highway, for not only the transportation of goods, but for the transportation of equipment, building supplies. Everything would become more expensive. And if we add to the maintenance costs of the highway the necessity to make ‘owners’ a profit, i.e. to charge a price in excess of the cost, then the cost of transportation becomes an enormous burden. The internet is the communication highway. The economy, and society in general, would benefit if the fee for use of that highway were eliminated. Of course internet businesses would still be able to thrive. Most of the content that the internet makes available is like the roadside cafe, the motel beside the highway. The restaurant owner and the motel owner don’t want their customers to have to pay to drive to their businesses, or for the truckers to pay to bring them their frozen fries and bed linens. In this view the ‘internet’ is the infrastructure: the equipment and services provided by the ISPs. The economy and society would benefit if the use of these services came at no direct cost to the users. The tax whiners who would rather pay a for-profit corporation $100 rather than pay a tax of $10? So to answer the question : the use of the internet could become 'free’ if it were acknowledged to be an essential public communication infrastructure. Just as highways are acknowledged to be essential public transportation infrastructure. That it is considered to be a privately owned service imposes a tax on all internet communication placing a private toll on communications , a confiscatory profit driven tax on commercial transactions thus raising prices and reducing profits while reducing aggregate demand through the inflation of prices for consumption.

The two aren't equal. TV and radio are one way: they are broadcast to you. Neither TV nor radio are content creation systems, they're content delivery systems. To interact with the radio, you have to call on the phone or write a letter, both of which you pay to use.  The Internet by virtue of its content creation and community forming abilities offers so much more. As such, I don't think internet will ever become a public commodity like we've seen TV and radio become. Thinking about this further, this brings up the whole 'tiered internet' thing: a few channels on TV are free, but most people pay a bunch more for extra content. Will there be a free version of the internet with limited access to content (text/images only, perhaps), but you have to pay for a higher tier of broadband for videos or web apps? If you're going to get a free version of the internet, I think it's going to be to a very limited subset of content, just like TV.  Also, Finland making internet a fundamental right does NOT make it free: the government mandated that telecommunications companies must cover 100% of the population with broadband, but nothing in there says it has to be offered for free. It just has to be available.

Nothing is "free." The Internet, starting with Internet access (bandwidth) and then moving to the core and the content (and related infrastructure), are both resources... if anything, they are energy.  They are finite resources, and have applicable value. Ever is a long time, but if the Internet is "free".... then in the foreseeable future it is just being subsidized my something/someone... a government, corporation, whatever.  Gmail is not free; nothing is free.  Any "free" Internet will be subsidized by advertising, if not something else. Should the Internet be considered a utility?Sure, as I understand the legal definition in the United States (I am not a lawyer nor have studied law), I believe it would be a good idea to classify and treat "broadband access" as a utility.  Further, specific rights should be clarified regarding the Internet and digital data.

One of my mentors used to say "Anything that's 'free' has been paid for twice already". No place would he be more correct than in this case. It's ridiculously expensive to acquire, operate, maintain and upgrade the infrastructure necessary to operate ANY Internet Service Provider. Scale up, there's a non-linear cost increase. Someone's gotta pay for that. However, as Patrick W. Gilmore posits, it's very likely to have scenarios in which you get bandwidth as part of a bundle, not separately priced. Like office space, or an apartment, or possibly moving into a particular neighborhood. But someone, somewhere is paying for the bits to get from here to there. And guess what? It's you!

Yes, eventually it will be free. Exp. You can get a free lifeline cellphone now which was unheard of 10 years ago. Furthermore, it’s unethical to charge for streaming data because they did not create that data. It’s as if I’m selling you pirated music. Advertisers should be paying for stuff like that and it should be subsidized by the government because it’s of national interest. Also as technology improves abundance follows. Corporations will however try to maintain the divide and rule paradigm and milk everyone individually as long as they can, but eventually it will cost more not to have everyone on the grid. The future of traffic, self driving cars , among other things, all that will require that everyone’s on the same page. Pinching a buck here and there from people individually wont be feasible. Amazon wants you to be on the internet so you can buy stuff from them.

A2A: Will internet access become free in the future? Where the Internet is concerned, ‘free’ generally just means that you aren’t paying money for something. There is always a payback somewhere, and at the moment this is your data and a channel to push ads back at you. The latter is of course little different to commercial TV but the former is effectively more lucrative than the value of the ‘free’ bandwidth. In the UK, Labour’s proposal for ‘nationalised’ free broadband at the last election was largely derided, but when governments are increasingly turning to online delivery of services and an associated decline of public facilities through underfunding, some kind of access becomes necessary in order not to deny access. It can’t be assumed that everyone has access to an internet-capable mobile phone, and this means there is a small, but significant gap in provision. Facebook attempted to offer free ’basic’ internet in India a few years ago but abandoned it following questions about who curated which sites were included in the product. Any kind of free internet would almost certainly be based on this model, and more so at a time where many nations are heading towards increasing control and surveillance of their population, ‘free’ internet access could potentially be another route to information gathering and dissemination.

I'm going to disagree with everyone else. Internet access may become "free" for some people, depending on your definition of free. For instance, I could see a future where in some places, Internet just "comes" with rent in an apartment building, a phone plan, cable TV, etc. There are already places where you can get a subset of the Internet for "free" with ads. This does not mean it is 100% free, though. Remember, if you are not the customer, you are the product. And getting a something free with a larger purchase just means the cost is in that larger price. But some people like their free gift in their Happy Meal or cereal box. If you are one of those, you may get "free" Internet someday. Or maybe not. What do I know?

It will be, when you people are content watching pre-determined content on a screen, with the limited notions of interactivity and control. Which is what TV and Radio have been historically. So, in essence, no. The Internet is supposed to be an advancement in content creation, distribution and monetization and it will likely remain that. Having said that, there will be bundled models where access is free. For instance, the Amazon Kindle. Cost of Internet access is subsidized into the device price. Similarly, Governments could ensure that their citizens have basic Internet access at least. For instance, Finland recently made access to the Internet a fundamental right. They could potentially subsidize the cost of access for lower-income groups.

The only thing in life you consume that is free is air; everything else has a cost associated with it.  Do you expect phone calls to be free?  How about electricity for your house?  The infrastructure to be an ISP costs real money.  ISPs are not in the business because, out of the goodness of their corporate hearts, they want to allow people to access the Internet.  ISPs are in the business to make money.  ISPs offer people the ability to get on the Internet for a fee in order to (1) recoup their infrastructure investment, and (2) to make a profit.

No, that's not going to happen. Running the Internet consumes a lot of resources and effort on people's part. That's got to get paid for somehow. It's conceivable (and a bad idea) that some government might choose to pay for it out of taxes, but make no mistake, that's not free.

The internet is becoming a utility like water and electricity. In some circumstances we don't directly pay but that is mostly because the costs are bundled elsewhere. For example some building owners are including Internet service as part of the rent to simplify things for renters. But fundamentally nothing that requires resources, infrastructure and people will ever be free. Just the cost can be hidden, bundled or moved.

No. Simply because the amount of resources it actually takes ISP’s to deploy and manage the hardware/software required to make such “connections” available, is only available at the cost of some form of monetary value. Spending millions (maybe even more) of dollars to manage the backbone of the internet, and supplying it for “free” would be an illogical business move, thus impractical and to deploy in the real world since the initial ROI (Return On Investment) would be negative Even such “free” internet commonly found in public areas, such as: Fast food chainsCoffee shopsOpen commercial officesAre all being retained publicly and distributed through some form of “pay-to-host” method Nothing is truly ever free, this is always some form of payment

Free internet means that every person is able to reach any website or network without any access restrictions (password, username etc). Internet, as everyone knows, is just a network of routers connected with each other such that any node can communicate with any other node. The requests Are served by servers (hosts on the internet). It is these hosts that have access restrictions because they may belong to defence, private company networks, telecommunication nodes or any other restricted domain( deep web). Such restrictions exist to keep certain information in closed groups. Hence the internet is not free. Now, lets just take the rest of the available internet in question. How does a person access the internet? Obviously via a telecom company or an ISP. Hence, again, telecom company or the ISP has control over what a user can access and can block certain websites ( remember the recent ban on torrent and file sharing websites due to SOPA-PIPA). So even the rest of internet is not free and has the ISP or telecom companies as gate keepers.

A2A: Of course not. There are costs involved. It takes equipment. Would you have ever wondered if phone service would become free in the future? It might happen for some who are willing to subscribe to a service which imposes advertisements. I.e., free in the sense that over-the-air broadcast TV is free. The price you pay is that you must endure the ads. In any case, you will still have to buy the equipment which exploits the connection at your end. Note that when businesses offer “free” Wi-Fi, they do expect you to do some business with them. If you use their Wi-Fi without permission, that would be stealing.

There are carriers offering 'free access', but usually as a promotional offer or as a bundle. For example, Softbank is offering Free DSL together with a free femtocell -- but that is to attract customers to their cellular service, so it is a promotion (much like the free cellphone). Here is a discussion of some 'free' offerings in the UK, including SKY's 20Mbps offer: http://www.broadbandchoices.co.uk/free-broadband.html Of course, TV & radio are not free either: they may be paid for by subscribers (cable), tax (BBC license fee) or advertisers (you pay for your TV in the price of your groceries). I have seen some examples of ad-supported ISPs but I don't think any successful ones?

Will internet access become free in the future? WiFi is already available freely, minus the purchase of the WiFi station that is broadcasting the SSID and the price the PROVIDER charges per month. Otherwise connecting to a WiFi’s SSID so long as it is not secured to prevent UNAUTHORIZED use is free already and has been for some years now. Stealing someones WiFi and using it freely probably will not be available so long as people can not be trusted.

It’s available freely now. It doesn’t require a spectrum license, or anything else. Anyone can set up WiFi by going and buying an access point and configuring it. There are some restrictions on output power but that’s about the only legal limitation on it.

Hi. The internet is free but connecting to it isn't. I mean if you don't buy data there is always a hidden cost to it when you connect. Free Internet is always or usually state sponsored meaning they pay for the internet using our tax money. So to snswer your question, its very hard to tell if connecting to the Internet will ever be free.

There is no such thing as free stuff. It is just a matter of who is paying. You can get free internet at Starbucks and McDonald's, but they pay for it and expect you to buy stuff from them while you are using their free Wifi. If government provides it for free, they pay for it with your tax dollars or someone else's tax dollars. The government doesn't have any money that they didn't take from someone. Even when they print new money they create inflation which reduces the value of everyone's money.
Nothing is ever free, sonwhile the service may be “free" to use someone will be footing the bill.

Yeah, why not? In our city there's a publicly available free wifi. I don't think it will be free wifi all over the world (unless someone figures out what Tesla was building) but in city cores? We're already there
I think internet access will be free for consumers, but not free of charge because someone's will pay instead of them for financial reasons (increase business income).
Internet IS already free to use. But accessing it not. Nor should it be. Nothing comes without you pay for it. Either you pay or you are the payment!!! I rather pay.
